Clinton used his connections to get him a deferral for no reason.

First, any foot problem eliminates drafting & enlisting. I have a relative who couldn't enlist or be drafted because he had a bunion on his right foot by the big toe, and a hammer toe.  Clinton was draftable, having registered the same year as Trump.  He had taken advantage of college deferments which were cancelled.  He relentlessly ppursued ways to get out of the draft.  First, he had a Democrat influencial uncle try to get him off, than others.  Further proof of his draft dodging, is in his letter he wrote thanking Colonel Holmes, head of the ROTC program at Arkansas University for helping him: "First, I want to thank you, NOT JUST FOR SAVING ME FROM THE DRAFT, but for being so kind....."  written in 1969.  Colonel Holmes later wrote about it, included in the Congressional Record, saying he was deceived by Clinton when he promised he would enroll in Arkansas Univeristy Law School & join it's ROTC program.  He never kept his promises and went to England to attend Oxford, where he made public speeches that he was against the American draft, no one should be drafted, & should avoid the draft.  Colonel Holmes said Clinton betrayed him, the Armed Services & his country, with his broken promises & oversea's attacks.

context: I love thrifting.

There is an Elton John/Bernie Taupin song. It is called “Oceans Away”. “I hung out with the old folkes, in the hopes that I’d get wise. I was trying to bridge the gap, between the great divide. Hung on every recollection, in the theater of the eyes. Picking up on this and that, from the few who still survive. Call them up, dust them off , let ‘em shine. The ones who hold onto the ones they had to leave behind. Those that flew and those that fell, the ones who had stay, beneath the wooden crosses, oceans away.” My dad enlisted in ‘43 at 17 and fought in the Battle of the Bulge. Check out the song. It is truly beautiful.

I have a few hundred letters that my father sent to his parents during WW II. They start from when he showed up at Fort Devens in MA and end when he was leaving Pakistan after serving as a C-47 crew chief in the CBI theater.

One time I went to a Good Will and found an old dresser. Well I needed one and didn't have much money so I bought it and after lugging it and wrestling it into my car, I drove home with it and lumbered into my apartment with it. The next day when I opened the bottom drawer when cleaning the thing thoroughly, I found a hidden compartment with a map to the lost city of el dorado. Now I'm a trillionaire. context: I saved and archived many similar family treasures dating to the earliest days of the 20th century. Sadly, although there are a number of young heirs, none are interested. As a historical librarian once told me, “they’ll be interested someday, but by then it will be too late”.

replies.context: Exactly.....the 20- and 30-somethings aren't interested at ALL. Nothing that we have to pass on to them resonates with them. All they are interested in is technology and $$$. I am a teacher, writer, former librarian and I have over 5K books in my personal library. NONE of my kids are interested in them and, what is worse, most libraries I contact aren't interested either. For most people the past (and I include people in that term) is nothing but a burden. Letter-writing is a lost art. Future historians will not be able to write the history of our times because of emails/texts that are deleted.
Future historians won't be able to decipher cursive writing.

I have the same problem in my family. No interest whatsoever in their connection to heirlooms.  My parents are gone now, of course and I treasure their stories and wish i knew more. All of that will die with me. What little family I have left is not even interested in my own story, let alone those that came before me.
